awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Real-Time: Collaborative Research: Unified Theory of Model-based and Data-driven Real-time Optimization and Control for Uncertain Networked Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The project seeks to find a common decision-making framework that seamlessly integrates offline data and computing, real-time data and computing, learning, and probabilistic predictive decision. It provides a unified theory of model-based and data-driven real-time optimization and control for uncertain networked systems. Integral Reinforcement Learning holds the key to integrating real-time data-driven methods, model-based methods, and physical constraints. The structure of Integral Reinforcement Learning will be explored to investigate exactly how and where to use Deep Learning neural networks in architectures that have multiple nested learning loops. A probabilistic spatiotemporal scenario data-driven framework will then be developed for multi-scale sequential control of networked engineering systems under uncertainty. The algorithms and tools developed will be used to sculpt optimal power profiles for power electronics converters in a DC distribution network and help mitigate the adverse effects of intermittent sources, uncertain load demand, or faults.
 
The project represents a radical departure from the exiting big data and decision-making research, toward developing autonomous decision-making under uncertainty constructs for systems of growing scales and time critical mission requirements.  Algorithms and tools developed can be extended to other smart and connected domains, e.g., air traffic management, networked traffic platoons, and sensor networks. US microgrid capacity is expected to reach 4.3 GW by 2020. DC distribution networks are emerging alternatives to AC distribution ones, and are critical to the scalable integration of renewable energy resources and electrified transportation fleets. Research results will be ported into topics in reinforcement learning, optimal control, networked control systems, data-driven analysis and decision-making, and power electronics systems. This project synergizes research activities between University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) and Texas A&M-Corpus Christi (TAMUCC), both HBCU/MI Hispanic Serving Institutions, and involves students from Electrical Engineering and Computer Science backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This EAGER proposal is the nexus of three integrated Scientific Thrusts with significant outcomes in the topical areas of the Solicitation.  In Scientific Objectives there were three Research Thrusts: (1) Deep Reinforcement Machine Learning for Automatic Feedback Control, (2) Probabilistic spatiotemporal data-driven decision-making for Uncertain Networked Systems. (3) Learning to self-heal in networked DC power distribution systems.

In the first Research Thrust, Deep Reinforcement Machine Learning provides a unified theory of model-based and data-driven optimization. We developed a new theory for Deep Learning neural networks in architectures that have multiple nested learning loops, including Bayesian belief updates, and provided formal proofs of control stability and performance.  We pioneered a new scientific field of discovery known as Adversarial Apprentice Games using our new algorithms for Inverse Reinforcement Learning. In Inverse RL, the unknown motivations and control strategies of an Expert Teacher are reconstructed and mimicked by a Novice Learner Agent.  Both model-based and data-driven algorithms were developed.

In the second research thrust, a probabilistic spatiotemporal scenario data-driven framework has been developed for multi-scale sequential control of networked engineering systems under uncertainty. The framework features a seamless integration of offline and online computing to meet real-time decision requirement through scalable uncertainty evaluation and fast query that exploit spatiotemporal correlations. We successfully applied the solution to the automated playbook design for UAV traffic management. In addition, we further investigated the estimation of influence model to capture spatiotemporal processes, the decision under uncertainty in the reinforcement learning and game frameworks, or the application to smart grids.

In the third research thrust, control protocols have been devised for the proper operation of power electronics-based buffers. DC power distribution networks are often weak grids with low generational inertia and damping. Herein, power buffers, that precede point-of-load converters, temporarily shield the power distribution network from abrupt load changes. Assistive control strategies have been devised while respecting the nonlinear nature of power electronics systems. The impact of the communication network on the controller performance is studied for power buffers in a DC microgrid. A family of robust controllers is designed for power buffers that consider loading uncertainties. Loads of stochastic nature have been considered.

 

In Broader Impacts we achieved significant Technology Transfer. We applied for a Patent under our Bayesian Belief theory of Thrust 1. In Technology Dissemination, under the EAGER grant topics we published numerous journal papers and two books. We were invited to give numerous talks at universities worldwide. We received a Best Paper Award from IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion and a Best Paper Award at IEEE International Conference on Control and Automation.

In Human Resources Training and Nurturing, under this grant and leveraging funding we advised 10 PhD students, including 5 females.  We advised and nurtured 4 Undergraduate minority and female students and 4 Master’s students in our Autonomous Systems Lab at UTA Research Institute.  We worked with visiting PhD students, including 3 females, from other universities to publish numerous journal papers. In outreach to industry, we trained 10 Engineers from Local Industry under our Online Controls and Systems Course curriculum. In Teaching Impact Curriculum development, we developed new material from this grant and posted some of the course notes online.
